description: Return to a home you never knew you missed with a visit to Gibson House, a 19th-century farmhouse hidden between the high rises of North York. Step across the threshold and back in time to the 1850s kitchen. Feel welcomed by the warm aroma of wood smoke and beeswax. Explore how David Gibson—Scottish immigrant, land surveyor, farmer, politician and rebel—put his mark on a community, a city and the province. Gibson House offers visitors an opportunity to taste, smell and touch history in a way that few other museums can. Let your senses come alive in this engaging historical family home. Admission General admission is free. Some exhibitions and events may carry a separate charge where noted. Hours of Operation Wednesday to Sunday: 11 a.m. to 4 p.m.

reviews.title: Wonderful
text: Wonderful visit, the museum looks like a cottage in the middle of high rise buildings. Museum staff were so generous and they have guided us through family history. A must visit place, highly recommended!

reviews.title: Nice little musuem
text: Found the museum by accident, having noticed it across the road from our hotel. Not a particularly large place though very interesting and the staff were very friendly and happy to spend the time explaining about the house and those who had lived there. Best of all it was free to visit, which was incredible given that a similar attraction in the UK wouldn't be a cheap day out. Worth searching out.

reviews.title: The little hidden gem of a museum in North York- must visit
text: The little Gem in North York- must visit.
I live close by and did not visit this museum till a relative came by and we had a free afternoon.

We had the most AMAZING tour with Mr. Booker. His knowledge, combined with his enthusiasm, made the 60 minutes seem short. We learned so much about Toronto, the colorful characters, the rebellion, and the life around Toronto.. I wish they would teach history like this!

reviews.title: Hearth cooking a real treat
text: We went to the Winterlicious supper at Gibson House.  It was a roast beef dinner prepared over the open fire in the kitchen.

Sheena did a wonderful job of dividing jobs up so everyone was involved in preparation of the meal and each dish was properly cooked and ready at the correct time, all the while giving a full commentary on the Gibson family and life in 1851.  After preparing the meal we all sat down to eat it by candle light in the dining room.
They don't do these meals too often so if you get the chance to attend one I highly recommend it.

reviews.title: Tour
text: Awesome Heritage Home of a respected family in Toronto. Not too many Toronto sites from 1850s are still remaining. Loved the personal tour and the ability to roam around on ones own afterwards! Will be back again soon!

reviews.title: Gibson House and Museum in Toronto, Ontario
text: Gibson House is a heritage museum showing 19th-century domestic arts and rural life skills besides culinary and textile arts. The original owner of the house was David Gibson who was a land surveyor who helped map early Toronto. He was wanted by the government for participating in the Upper Canada Rebellion of 1837 and therefore he was forced to flee to the United States where he and his family remained for 11 years. Eventually the Gibsons built this beautiful home and once again became active members of their rural community.In Gibson Park there is also a public art installation and a large granite wall etched with photos of the Gibson descendants.

reviews.title: Highly recommended
text: Nice place, great staff, cozy environment.
I love tea and traditional biscuits they served.
It was great.

reviews.title: Very nice museum
text: The Gibson House Museum was a very beautiful and historical place, it was very nice to see all the relics and tools in David Gibson’s house. The guids were also very nice and cheerful and dressed in period attire. I was also treated to tea and cookies made in a open fire. Would definitely reccomend

reviews.title: Charming but needs improvement
text: I discovered this place while researching for places to visit. I really enjoyed the Harvest Festival. The lady making the apple fritters was quite grumpy.Inspite of her,my friends and I enjoyed the delicious fresh goodies. We learned a bit of history about the house. After that visit, we decided to try the Victorian Seance. Unfortunately that was a bust. It was not a real seance. More like a childish game of let's try the Ouija board.Our next event was the Victorian Tea which was dismal. The worst tea experience I've ever had. A bit stingy with the scones and sandwiches. For a first time visit it's interesting. Repeat visits will wear you down.

reviews.title: A bit of history right in the middle of the modern
text: Gibson House presents the visitor with local history in a quiet oasis amongst the busy downtown area.
Within easy walk from the subway and pleasant to contrast the old building with the modern in a calm park setting.

We visited on Thursday evening - the museum is open until 20:00 with an honesty payment system, and no guided tour.  For me this was better as I usually prefer to go round myself and look at things quietly on my own anyway.

All the rooms are set out well with artefacts suitable for the period and some explanations and descriptions provided.  Two highlights, the exhibition of purses and their contents with an area to display and photograph the contents of your own purse and upload it to the website.  Also curiously, a picture on the wall, of a print entitled "The spree of Melton Mowbray"  Just had to look that one up.
I was also introduced to a Victorian game, called 'Graces' played with sticks and a hoop.
Great value for money and an interesting 90 minutes.

reviews.title: Just OK
text: If you're determined to see all of Toronto's historic homes, otherwise I can't really recommend it. The house is pretty small, easily seen in its entirety in about 30 minutes, and the surrounding grounds are pretty scant. I definitely enjoyed visiting places like Spadina House & Colborne Lodge a lot more.

reviews.title: Excellent museum of local history!
text: The Gibson House is a museum dedicated to the man who helped lay out the plans for the city of Toronto.  My friend and I took a tour there one day and we thoroughly enjoyed it!  The tour guide was so good, informative and interactive, as well as kind and well mannered.  The whole group enjoyed her tour so much we clapped at the end when it was over!  We also got to taste home-made ice cream using a recipe of the times, and it was delicious.  The museum is right on the steps of the North York Central subway station, and so it's easily accessible.  Recommended!

reviews.title: good neighbourhood historical site
text: A good place to visit with children or out of town guests.  It's a small place so nice to combine the visit with another activity.

reviews.title: Got to tailor the tour
text: The dear old docent welcomed me and my overseas friend, promptly sat us down in the living room a horse-hair couch, and launched into a 15-minute lecture on Mister Gibson and his times. Sadly, she didn't get the hint when my friend's eyes glazed over and his head started nodding erratically. Lovely lecture, though, for someone with a background in the War of 1812 and Canada's independence.

But why not jump instead in medias res, right in Mister Gibson's office or the servant's quarters? And please, we did say we did rock our heels and say we're headed out to Niagara-on-the-Lake, so let's move along!

But she was a pleasant and helpful guide overall, and the furniture and stuff authentic looking. Just that it would be nice to have had the guided tour tailored for those with a different agenda and background.

reviews.title: another historic site of the city
text: i wasnt impressed and i dont really recommend this place to anyone,,is just an old house with its own story,,they do have some Christmas activities for kids though..like making cookies,,writing a letter to santa n stuff,,so i guess kids will buy it

reviews.title: Mother's Day Tea & House Tour - A Special Treat!!!
text: For $25 you get a lovely afternoon tea with finger sandwiches, especially baked desserts, and freshly made scones.  Mom's also get a little gift of tea.  You also get to tour the house which is very informative and interesting with helpful period dressed guides.  There is also a little museum and gift area.  We bought little area rugs made by the volunteers who used the loom in the house.  Gibson House also offers various events throughout the year which are worth exploring.

reviews.title: North York history
text: This is a well preserved house and the oldest in North York, just off Yonge St.  It gives a very good idea of what life was like for the well-to-do almost 200 years ago. Visit the nearby 150 year old apple tree in Gibson Square.

reviews.title: Small historic escape
text: This small museum 19th Century home is a nice escape hidden in the very busy neighbourhood of Norht Toronto.   Check out the special activity days....a great short escape in time

reviews.title: History In Our Own Backyard
text: Having lived in Toronto for over 45 years, I have only recently decided to explore the fascinating history of the events that occurred in this city, and to visit some of the structures that still stand from the pre-confederation days

The Gibson House is one such structure that should be visited by those who are keen on Toronto's role in Canadian history, and the Upper Canada Rebellion of 1837-38 (as well as the William Lyon Mackenzie House - in downtown Toronto).
The tour is very well done, informative, inexpensive and well worth the one hour it will take to complete.
Cool fact: There is an apple tree from the original Gibson farm that still stands today a few yards from the house that dates back to the mid 1800's
Check out this place...get to know your own city.

reviews.title: Very charming trip back in time
text: An old house turned into a museum lets visitors experience what life was like for early Canadians a couple of centuries ago. The house itself is only a handful of furnished rooms but the staff (some costumed) are ready to engage you in a trip back in time with lots of interesting details about the everyday life of the Gibsons. Beautiful herb and vegetable garden. Very reasonable admission prices and free parking! If you are a city of Toronto resident and have a valid Toronto Public Library card enquire at your library about a free Toronto Historic Museums pass to visit the Gibson House.

reviews.title: Lovely little house
text: Gibson house is a small house that shows that days living style. There was a guide who guide us throw the house and explain everything for us. The ticket price is about 6$ that really worth it.

reviews.title: Excellent and engaging tour.
text: Great tour of the historic house.  Lots of activities to engage kids in learning about history and the Discovery Gallery was a big hit.

reviews.title: Fun safe place to learn about old toronto
text: This museum just north of the 401 is an ideal place to spend two hours and do a picnic with the 6 to 10 year old. Nestled in between two 50+storey condos the 18th cemetery home of the first suyveyour of north York ( Toronto ) couple with Boeing of Dempsey house around the corner and a picnic in the gazebo.

reviews.title: Very nice museum
text: The Gibson House is set back on Yonge Street, in North York, close to the subway station.  It is a very interesting museum built in 1851 by David Gibson, a Scottish immigrant, land surveyor, local politician and farmer who took part in the 1837 Rebellion - who was then exiled to the US for 10 years, and came back to rebuild his home.  He lived in this house with his wife and their 7 children.  The house has been very nicely restored and is well maintained.   I visited on a Sunday afternoon and at the end of the tour, we were treated to tea and home made cookies.  The tour guides were great, knowledgeable, and helpful.  They were engaging and made you feel very welcome. There is a small shop where you can purchase gifts and or treats.  Well worth the visit.  A very small fee is required.  Pair this museum with a lunch and a great way to spend the afternoon.

reviews.title: Local gem
text: The Gibson house is a local gem that shares what it was like to live in North York when it was simple a few settlers and farmland. Although now it's a bit difficult to find because it is eclipsed by skyscrapers that adds to the beauty of it. Past and present mix right on historic Yonge Street!

There are wonderful programs there as well for families and children. I had my daughter's birthday party at the museum and it was educational, fun and cost effective. The staff stayed in character and we learned what life was life living in the house for children and adults of the time period.
